data.name: DenutritionDetailPageContent
data.value:
Severely underweight: Malnutrition is a condition resulting from inadequate nutrient intakes in relation to energy expenditure of the organization. When inputs are inadequate as well as being insufficient, we speak of malnutrition. Malnutrition is classified to section marasmus of the International Classification of Diseases.
Pathophysiology Malnutrition can have multiple origins. The etiology is varied and may involve an organic disease, psychiatric or social. Undernutrition is called primary when it is induced by a direct cause, and secondary when it is caused in result of another condition. There are two pathophysiological mechanisms: lack of inputs and hypermetabolism.
Malnutrition deficiency of contributions In case of deficiency of contributions is set up the fasting state, which evolves in several steps. Energy sources in fasting are, for glucose metabolism, the use of hepatic glycogen and glucose synthesis and for lipid metabolism, the use of fatty acids and ketogenesis.
* Fasting immediate adaptation to the food taken intermittently for less than twelve hours. Insulin secretion decreases, while glucagon increases. This game leads to hormonal stimulation of lipolysis and fatty acid oxidation and ketogenesis. To maintain blood glucose, glycogenolysis is stimulated exclusively.
* Fasting short: adaptation to the absence of food intake over a period of twelve hours to three or four days. Insulin secretion decreases further. Depletion of glycogen causes a decrease in blood glucose. The only source of glucose in the body becomes gluconeogenesis, which produces glucose from amino acids in muscle protein manufacturing urea as waste. The excretion of urea therefore increases. Ketogenesis continues.
* Prolonged Fasting: after about five days to several weeks. Plasma ketone bodies increased, while the excretion of urea stabilizes at 50 mg / kg / day. This stabilization is related to stabilization of the savings referred to proteolysis protein. New hormonal changes occur, with a decreased production of thyroid hormones. This phase of prolonged fasting results in marasmus.
* Terminal stage: When fat stores are depleted, plasma levels of fatty acids and ketone bodies are lowered, while the blood sugar rises. Indeed, there is then an increased mobilization of skeletal muscle protein for gluconeogenesis. This leads to increased excretion of urea and nitrogen and results in high morbidity and mortality.
Credit Wikipedia: http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dénutrition

data.name: MaigreurDetailPageContent
data.value:
Thinness:
Thinness is the state of what is lean. In the case of a person is referred to as underweight. As such, it is defined by the World Health Organization as the abnormal condition of individuals whose BMI is between 15 and 18.5. Pathological thinness increases the risk of various diseases among which include infections and osteoporosis but may also be a symptom of one of them. It can also be a non-pathological state, that is to say constitutional, stable and not accompanied by any disturbance. ÉtiologieLes causes can be
* Sociological famine, poverty * Psychiatric: anorexia nervosa, depression * Medical: neoplasia, severe infection (tuberculose. ..), type 1 diabetes, addiction, disease with intestinal malabsorption, AIDS ... * Genetics: Hereditary * Morphology: thin bones, muscles purposes * The Constitutional thinness
Credit Wikipedia: http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maigreur

data.name: NormalDetailPageContent
data.value:
It should not be confused mass (severe) and weight. The weight of a body is a force, mainly due to the action exercised upon him the gravitational field.
Reserves in respect of BMI It is important to keep in mind that BMI is only an indicator, not an absolute given. Because of their muscle mass, some athletes have a BMI above 25 kg/m2, they incur no danger. Moreover, according to the morphology of a person's BMI varies in good shape. A person may be squat without being oily (eg Bixente Lizarazu, Mike Tyson or Jonah Lomu), and another may have a slender but too much body fat. Also, keep in mind the limits of the thresholds recommended by WHO. They are convenient to use, these thresholds should ideally vary by sex, age and ethnicity and they should apply with caution to individual diagnosis. The judgment of its weight through the fat mass index should be done with the help of a doctor and seeing a nutritionist or dietitian is recommended.
Credit Wikipedia: http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indice_de_masse_corporelle

data.name: ObesiteDetailPageContent
data.value:
Obesity is the condition of an individual with a body mass well above what is desirable or acceptable, usually due to an accumulation of body fat. The human obesity has been recognized as a disease in 1997 by WHO. This organization defines "overweight and obesity as an abnormal or excessive accumulation of body fat that can harm health." Its prevention is a public health problem in developed countries. It can have a significant impact on the health of the individual. This multifactorial disease is now seen metaphorically as a pandemic, although this is not an infectious disease.
Definition The clinical forms are numerous, with the pathophysiological mechanisms and pathological consequences different, so it is better to speak of "obesity". To evaluate these obesity should be analyzed two parameters that affect the complications of the disease independently from each other: excess body fat, and fat distribution.
Phenotypes 4 types of obesity are described: * Type I: excess fat is distributed in the body without preferential localization; * Type II: excess fat is concentrated on the trunk and abdomen: it comes to abdominal obesity; * Type III: fat accumulation occurs in the abdomen: it comes to visceral obesity; * Type IV: the fat is localized in the hips and thighs (glutéofémoral level): this is a gynoid obesity.
Credit Wikipedia: http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obésité

data.name: ObesiteSevereDetailPageContent
data.value:
Obesity is the condition of an individual with a body mass well above what is desirable or acceptable, usually due to an accumulation of body fat. The human obesity has been recognized as a disease in 1997 by WHO. This organization defines "overweight and obesity as an abnormal or excessive accumulation of body fat that can harm health." Its prevention is a public health problem in developed countries. It can have a significant impact on the health of the individual. This multifactorial disease is now seen metaphorically as a pandemic, although this is not an infectious disease.
Definition The clinical forms are numerous, with the pathophysiological mechanisms and pathological consequences different, so it is better to speak of "obesity". To evaluate these obesity should be analyzed two parameters that affect the complications of the disease independently from each other: excess body fat, and fat distribution.
Phenotypes 4 types of obesity are described: * Type I: excess fat is distributed in the body without preferential localization; * Type II: excess fat is concentrated on the trunk and abdomen: it comes to abdominal obesity; * Type III: fat accumulation occurs in the abdomen: it comes to visceral obesity; * Type IV: the fat is localized in the hips and thighs (glutéofémoral level): this is a gynoid obesity.
Credit Wikipedia: http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obésité

data.name: SurpoidsDetailPageContent
data.value:
Overweight is the state of a person with a BMI considered slightly higher than normal or average in a given society.
It is defined by the World Health Organization as an attribute of individuals with a BMI between 25 and 30 kilograms per square meter and is, according to these criteria, bounded by the thin (or normal weight) and 'moderate obesity.
Credit Wikipedia: http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surpoids
